The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: I live in a bustling big city, with a neighborhood that's as diverse as it gets. Residential areas are scattered among commercial districts, where you'll find all sorts of businesses - offices, stores, eateries, and entertainment spots. There's no shortage of places to eat or shop, ranging from giant corporate stores to cozy boutiques that line up along the streets, often within walking distance from peaceful neighborhoods. We've got a couple of nearby parks too, always filled with families and their young ones. The people here are a mix of folks - there's a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish group, and refugees/immigrants from the Soviet Union right in my neighborhood. Just a bit further out, you'll find enclaves like Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and more, all within a few miles' radius. But don't let that fool you - a 10-mile drive can easily take an hour or two due to heavy traffic, especially during peak hours. Few people walk around here; the city's so large that people prefer to commute by car. This means traffic's a nightmare, and parking's nearly impossible. Despite all this, there's been a lot of construction lately, with new apartment buildings popping up like mushrooms. While it's a popular destination, residents aren't thrilled about the prospect of more people and cars. We have all sorts of houses too - single-family homes, duplexes, and smaller apartment buildings. People of all ages live here, and I barely know most of my neighbors. It's not the tight-knit community it used to be when I was a kid, where I'd play outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends close to my age.

My neighborhood is quite unique. Most of the houses here are single-family homes, but a few have been divided into two units, still attached to each other. My home has a small front yard and a driveway to the left. Like many others, our neighborhood is a reminder of the time when life in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream once seemed to unify the people, but now it feels like it's slipping away. My neighborhood, along with many others, still clings to this dream, attracting visitors who feel it's still alive. Though the optimism of the past seems to have faded, and the upkeep of the yards has slackened, there's still a car in every driveway and kids playing as if the world revolves around them. The public school, standing for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire today's youth and stir up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are sparse and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full. Each home has its own character, yet they all feel the same. There's a massive supermarket called "Super A" owned by a large Yemeni family, likely the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The majority of residents are African American. The streets are spacious, and kids play football, pausing only for passing cars. Most residents have been here for generations, and many can spin tales of a past where everyone knew everyone. A karate school once operated here, but with the waning popularity of karate kid movies, it closed. Now it's a pharmacy, as many believe drugs can solve all problems. There's also a small movie theater that plays old films at discounted prices, attracting the elderly who enjoy a night out without the kids. A single expressway runs through our town, with the entrance and exit in the neighboring town. There was a petition to bring the exit to our town, but the elders opposed it, fearing it would ruin our community. They convinced the city council to reject the request. A new high school is being built, and we're debating a mascot. I suggest a cybernetic cowboy with a log cabin.

You might walk right past it without a second glance - after all, it's just a residential area behind a shopping strip, not the kind of place most people would think to look for a place to live. Behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and the hotels only occupied occasionally for family reunions, there's a whole bustling community. Amidst these communities, down the road, there are a few apartment complexes nestled together like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully pulled apart and lined up. The first apartments you come across are those that have been featured in the news for some unsavory activities, so we won't dwell on those too much. But the apartments next to that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole different story, almost unknown to anyone living in the area. Across from these complexes stands a community college's satellite campus, a quiet, sleepy set of buildings where students saunter in with coffee in hand at 7 in the morning to start their day. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters honk and groan at the traffic delays on days with higher attendance. The road intersects another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those who've broken bones on the other. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that whirls the warm, thick summer air. Children play cartwheels and pirouettes across the prickly grass in the park, while bees lazily buzz around the flower patches. Elderly folks stroll their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding at the girls gathered by the playground equipment, discussing boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There's a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park with inexpensive yet not too busy food, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon in between. You can fill your pool while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken - the perks of a strip mall. There's also a frozen yogurt place where teens often cling to cold, sweating cups of DIY frozen yogurt covered in toppings while doing tricks on their skateboards and vaping because they think it's cool. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where not much ever changes, not even time.

“Where is everything?” she asked, driving past the corn fields that stretched out before us. “This is it!” I replied, knowing she’d be taken aback by the vast openness. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a 5-minute walk from her house - she'd never seen this much space. The corn fields were a sight to behold, and I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio. As we drove along the two-lane country road, we passed a quarry filled with water, and just beyond that, the small development where I lived. The houses here were mostly made of brick and stucco, each with at least half an acre of land, which everyone took pride in maintaining. During spring, these driveways would be lined with the finest Mercedes-Benz luxury cars, gleaming after a thorough wash. Continuing towards my grey stucco home, I’d always see my Korean neighbor out, with a friendly face, spending the day tending to his lawn. He’d be singing over the hum of his mower, and everyone in the neighborhood would laugh, but he was always genuine and had an intriguing history. Once a doctor, he now spends his days blending in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower.

Reaching my home, we found a side yard filled with geese being chased by our Terrier. Out back, a small stream fed into the quarry, where you could hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from nearby farms. Across a handmade wooden bridge, there was an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent my childhood, building tree forts and “hunting” animals, which usually just meant chasing them. The winters here could be brutally cold, transforming the yard into a barren wilderness. Bare trees, once adorned with vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers, would turn into skeletal structures. Snowball fights were our favorite winter activity, with my sister and me building igloo-like forts to house our arsenal. In our winter wonderland, we’d play pretend, carefree and happy, without a worry in the world.

Portland, Oregon is a place that's all about embracing the strange. The unofficial town motto, as proudly displayed on a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and strip club (all while skirting the law on a few of these), is "Keep Portland Weird." Some people see it as a nod to Portland's creative and unique culture from the 90's and early 2000's, a time when the city was still relatively unknown and cheaper. For others, it's an invitation to join in the weirdness, where being called weird is a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the constant construction of apartment complexes to house them, Portland still holds onto its weirdness. Weird doesn't mean being open to everything, but it does mean being open to things that are unusual. Weird doesn't mean we're without modern conveniences or modern problems. We buy most of our stuff from China, just like the rest of the country. Portland has a million ways to be weird, to be not normal, but it also has plenty of normalcy. There's yoga and hipsters and business professionals galore. Maybe weird means we just don't take everything so seriously. In my neighborhood, like many in Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes are traditionally old cardboard boxes with items someone is giving away, but they can be plastic bags or boxes too. They contain magical treasures just waiting for the person who wanders by. They often have clothes and books, but they can have anything. Wandering through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about for me, but I'm just one variety of weird among countless others. Some people I live with would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. They'd rather go to goat yoga or support the city's soccer team, the Timbers. Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things and are full of dreams. Yes, Portland has a drug problem, which is often rooted in mental health issues. The constant rainy weather and dreary clouds don't help matters. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one seems to know how to tackle. Social services are better here than in many places, but they're still lacking. The homeless population is drawn by Portland's services, but our efforts are insufficient, just like everywhere else. The non-homeless population swings between concern and hatred. In this, we're not weird at all.

The mountains are always there, standing tall and steadfast in the north. They bear witness to the sun's daily rise and fall, and no matter how busy life and work become, they remain unchanging and unperturbed. On days when I feel most stressed and overwhelmed, they call to me, and when I turn to them, they offer a place of solace and strength to carry on, one day at a time. I first encountered these mountains when I moved here for undergrad, and they were instantly captivating. While the university and town have their own charms, it's the mountains that truly capture my heart. The town itself is beautiful with its own unique blend of old and new. There are countless cafes where many hours were spent with books and friends, and the downtown area offers a vibrant atmosphere with its historic brick buildings and bustling restaurants. This urban energy gives way to a quieter, more serene small-town feel just a short walk away, with the library serving as a dividing line between the two. This contrast of environments makes the city feel inviting, like a puzzle just waiting to be explored. Memories are made in each part of town, from late-night walks in the park with friends to catching a movie in the fancy theater provided by the university. However, it's not all sunshine and roses. The town is also home to many tough memories, and the ponds can serve as a place for reflection and even crying sessions, especially during existential crises. Watching the turtles and ducks go about their days has often left me questioning my own purpose in life. But after a while, I'd walk past the pond, park, and the familiar houses, until I reached a main street. There, the sun would cast its golden rays upon the palm trees, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was heading north. There they stood, as they always had, the mountains reaching up to the sky, their presence a beacon of unyielding strength. They spoke to me of perseverance, reminding me to carry on, one step at a time.

If you're thinking of visiting Bensonhurt in Brooklyn, you won't have a hard time finding it! Public transit is readily available and a favorite among New Yorkers. Bensonhurt is pretty urban, so you'll feel right at home in the city. While you're there, expect to see plenty of Asian stores. Over the past 20 years, Bensonhurt has become a hotspot for Asians, with Asian-owned businesses everywhere. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly common, and they're beloved by locals for their quality products and lower prices. I live nearby and can vouch for the convenience—there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other! But Bensonhurt isn't just Asian; it's very diverse, with immigrants, first-gen, and second-gen residents. Most major businesses are owned by Asians, and there's even a recently renovated park nearby with basketball and soccer fields, handball courts, swings, a kid-friendly playground, and a water fountain. New York's parks are diverse, and Bensonhurt is no exception. Most folks are nice, but it can get pretty noisy. Cars are often blaring music, and early morning gas revving can wake you up. After dark, stay alert; while Bensonhurt is generally safe, it can be unpredictable. I've had past experiences with bullying and package theft, but these incidents are rare. Dog waste is a common issue; you'll see plenty on your way to the train or supermarket. Keep your shoes clean, folks!

There aren't many sidewalks around here. My house sits right at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood, earning it the moniker "work out hill" for all the joggers who hit it daily. Since sidewalks are non-existent, everyone walks on the road. The road's in pretty bad shape, with a few potholes that make driving a bit of a challenge. The telephone and electric wires are a mess too, constantly being repaired due to the frequent storms and fallen branches, making them look like a patchwork quilt. Evergreen trees dot the landscape, but locals aren't fond of them, cutting down as many as possible to clear the view of the ocean. Many houses are built high up on the hill to take in the view of the bay, with large glass-fronted second stories. Sunsets here are stunning, with the water lighting up and the sky turning orange. But most days are cloudy and damp, with moss covering roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked for a month and had to spend three hours scraping off the moss. Kids are few and far between, but there's a school nearby. Most people are older, retired, with dogs being the common "children" in the neighborhood. Leave a door or window open, and you might find a dog in your living room. Rabbits run wild around the area, digging up gardens and lawns, much to the gardeners' dismay. My cats love them though, keeping most of them away. We get the usual birds too, from small sparrows and hummingbirds to the occasional hawk or eagle chased off by neighborhood crows. There aren't any stores nearby, but a hike downhill to the waterfront has a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. There's not much of a beach, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay isn't very wide, and you can see the opposite shoreline even through the mist on most days.

I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many folks move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live here. Everyone keeps themselves busy with yard work and other daily chores. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we take note of it. Some neighbors go walking for exercise or to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you'd expect from a quiet neighborhood. We're home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, myself, my wife, and two daughters aged eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Every now and then we grill outside on our back deck, and the smell of barbecue is always pleasant. It seems like there's always someone cutting grass around here, and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through October when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's plenty of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the fall as well. That means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I love the smell of burning leaves, so it's always a nice sign that fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door unless someone knocks on it, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. On holidays, it's pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town, and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. The same goes for other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is smack dab in the middle of the high desert, where dirt is as far as the eye can see. Unless you've lived here, it's hard to grasp the feeling of always seeing brown. When you do see a lawn, it means someone's dropping a fortune on lawn care. Back in the 90s, houses were scattered far and wide, but now it's the same story with new additions popping up. The place looks more like a city every day, but I guess that's how most places change. Most of the time, people are friendly, but like any city, there are good parts and bad. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly old folks, so I suppose it's a nice part of town. The stores here are mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for upscale shopping, you've got to travel. I've never seen a Whole Foods or any store like that here. The jobs that stand out the most are in construction, probably because this city is still developing, with plenty of open spaces to build on. That makes me a little nervous, as I like things just the way they are now. I came from a big city and there's no way I'm going back. Speaking of construction, that's what I do for a living. I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I love about my home is the variety of animals. People come here for the stark beauty of the desert, and the unique ecosystems created by the climate and topology. We've managed to coexist with the wildlife well. My kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs. As for attractions, we have some, and Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. If you're lucky, plan your visit to coincide with the annual San Bernardino County Fair. You can also visit nearby Wrightwood for snow-covered mountains and winter sports lessons. If you're interested in the natural history and culture of the desert, check out the Victor Valley Museum. It's got geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the area's development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm guessing my answer is a bit unique. Unlike others who might be homeowners with their own personal lives, my situation's a tad different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus I call home, and the people living in my dormitory to be my community. The surrounding campus is also part of my neighborhood, but to a lesser degree. Despite this peculiarity, there are common threads with conventional neighborhood life. Just like any other neighborhood, mine has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by talking about the houses that make up my neighborhood. Before diving into the specifics, it's crucial to clarify the types of housing you'll find. We have apartments, actual houses, and dormitory houses. First, in the apartments, you'll usually find 2-4 people in each room, with around 4-6 rooms per floor. A typical building can house about 20 people. Next, there are actual houses available for anyone affiliated with the school to rent. These are 2-4 bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. However, there are only a few of these scattered throughout the neighborhood due to efficiency concerns. Lastly, there are dormitory-style rooms that house hundreds of students. Here, two people share a room, with a few exceptions. This is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, let's move on to the people. My school emphasizes diversity, and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. People from all cultures and ages call this place home. Professional staff typically live in houses within the neighborhood, while newer students live in dorm-style housing and older students in apartment-style housing. It's hard to do justice to the people in this neighborhood, so let's move on to the stores and parks. Since the school is self-contained, it has a wealth of stores and a single park. You'll find a mix of dining options and the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Anything you need can be found within the neighborhood's boundaries! Plus, the park is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, kept clean and free of crime by its residents!

Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them. But my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only gone so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, which is why I enjoy living here. While there are mainly apartment buildings, a few restaurants and bars nearby provide fun nights out without breaking the bank. One of the bars recently got a name change and became more pricey, but the service and drinks aren’t too bad. The majority of people here are either college students or lower-income residents, which is reflected in the affordable housing. There's an elementary school within walking distance, adding to the neighborhood's lively atmosphere. My neighbors and I don’t interact much, but they don’t bother me. The building management even placed an air freshener near their door to combat the frequent marijuana smoke, which my boyfriend and I find amusing. The buildings in my area are mostly old, but some have been spruced up from the inside. Down the road, new apartment buildings have popped up, but their construction quality is questionable despite the high rent, all thanks to their prime campus location. There’s a cheap eatery nearby that serves food on paper plates and mostly microwaves its offerings. Across from it is a gas station, known for poor work conditions, but the city improved the street and sidewalks last year, making the area more pleasant. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street but 43rd street behind it isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are in poor condition, and the buildings look shabby. Many trees line this street, possibly to conceal the buildings' appearance. While crime happens at the apartments on 43rdstreet, I can’t single them out as the sole culprits. There are also problematic apartments across from mine with a transient population. Despite the challenges, I like where I live; it's affordable, and there are convenient amenities nearby, especially the university and bus stops for easy access to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood is a cul-de-sac lined with duplexes that look like standalone homes, each painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Most neighbors are friends, and we often gather at the end of the street to chat while kids play. It's like stepping back in time, surrounded by fields and trees, and blue skies with white clouds. This year, we're experiencing tornado warnings, and last night, we heard sirens. I found myself in my bathtub, clutching my little dog and a few pillows, while my bigger dog barked from the living room. The storm left the road steaming as the temperature dropped from 92 to 75. Hail melted instantly on the hot pavement. After the storm, a double rainbow appeared, and I snapped some photos to share with my friends and family. The neighborhood was quiet for an hour before people started returning home. Business as usual resumed, with moms and kids outside as dinner cooked. I love the southern accent here; it's a gem of a place to live, forty minutes from Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by rooster crows, and we have a donkey braying in the evening. I was fortunate to find this cozy community.

I moved here right before starting eighth grade. Making friends was tough at first, but I eventually hit it off with a buddy who lived two doors down and another guy on my street. They've since moved away, but the memories linger. The folks who've been here since I moved are still around, for the most part. Our neighborhood's pretty standard for suburban America, filled with two-story homes. Weekends and warm days bring kids playing outside, and it's usually quiet the rest of the time. I've never had issues with my neighbors, and I'd say I can trust them. A park a few minutes from my house holds many memories - basketball, football, baseball games, and even my worst memory, a painful elbow to the nose during a game. Today, I go there to bond with my cousin's kids, who love the swings and slides. The park fills me with nostalgia. Our neighborhood's diverse, with a variety of cuisines within a mile - Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian. Nowadays, folks often use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered. We've got all the stores you need, from dry cleaners to pharmacies, a grocery store, and even an Indian-owned shop for some authentic cuisine. In comparison to other places I've read about, I consider myself fortunate for my neighborhood.

My neighborhood is one of those small towns you might find scattered around South Carolina. It's nothing extraordinary, but it sure has a knack for peaches and farming, which is why Johnston is proudly known as the Peach Capital of the World. The town's welcome sign proudly boasts this title, and it's not hard to understand why. Most of the land around here is covered in peach orchards or cattle fields. Houses are spaced out, often two stories with either metal roofs to keep the summer sun at bay or gray shingles. They're usually not positioned near the road, allowing the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the main part of town, there's a solitary traffic light at a four-way intersection, and that's where you'll find all the stores! There's a quaint little Chinese restaurant called Hong Kong, a Fiesta Mexican spot, Gary's burger joint (which has a limited menu but is quite popular), and Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. You'll also find a small, upscale grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, and a Dollar General store that's bustling from morning till night. There's a furniture store, Possibilities, run by a kind woman who's well-respected in the community, and attached to it is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming service that offers daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, and bathing. The town has a single elementary school, Johnston Elementary, and students have to travel to the next town for middle and high school. There are no parks yet, but they're planning a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide more opportunities for families and attract visitors. Despite the lack of large stores, restaurants, or parks, it's a tight-knit community that makes you feel like you're part of something special!

The first time I heard about my place, it was while listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. I was taken aback, seeing that almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. None of my friends or I had ever heard that story before. Maybe it's because of the struggle we're all facing. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night, given how expensive things are. But we've become frugal over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell less in adulthood. You might pick up a cigarette or just get used to the way things are. But the flea market always has its place. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano, wedging itself into the leather and lingering even after you wash it. There are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting on the far side, you can visit two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you wouldn't hear that in the thrifts. No matter the crowd, the stores are eerily silent. It's a great place to lose an afternoon. Each year, the city swells with more and more people. It's a developing city, they say, with one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery. It reminds me of New York. Everyone is focused on their own goals, and you can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people won't bother you. It's not like the South, where being a bit concerned means you care deeply. You don't pry into anyone's life here. You can maintain your privacy for as long as you like, and the city will just flow around you like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment full of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn together, and help each other out when we can. I'm lucky to be here. I get along well with most of my neighbors, and they treat me pretty well too. I make sure to clean after myself and leave them food, and they do the same. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.

The area where I reside is a quintessential cookie-cutter suburb, with a homeowner's association that's evident right away. Upon entering, you'll see a uniform grid of well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the HOA. The front yards are all similar, with small patches of landscaped grass, a smattering of decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Occasionally, you might spot a small tree. Every household boasts a two-car garage. As you drive along the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete streets without any potholes, ensuring a smooth drive. Most homes are single-story, but every now and then, you'll find a two-story. Mailboxes are communal, with a large grouping at the end of the street, each requiring a key for access. There are also two larger lockers for packages, a system that keeps the community uniform, thanks to the HOA. My house is located on the outskirts of a nearby city, offering a blend of rural and suburban living with ample space. There are multiple community pools and walking trails for dog walks or leisurely strolls. The community is large enough that running around it provides plenty of exercise. The neighborhood is primarily retirement homes but also has a scattering of middle-aged and young professionals. The city itself is large in population but retains a small-town feel. We've got all the amenities you'd expect, such as one mall, no enormous but functional, with stores ranging from high-end grocery outlets to bargain outlets with limited staff. Everything is within a 15-minute drive, making it easy to get to major chains. Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and typical, with nice things like pools and walking trails, and while it's not right next to shopping, a car ride away will get you to any major chain you need.

I reside in a small Midwestern town, practically on the outskirts of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side, is the most economically underprivileged area. Most houses are rented by or owned by low-income individuals, but it's not unpleasant to live here. Neighbors here are generally friendly and wave hello as I walk down the street. Crime rates are a bit higher, with a few violent incidents, including shootings and one homicide, within a few blocks of my home over the past decade. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a nearby bar last year. Our family has had no direct involvement with crime apart from a few missing items from our porch. The town has been heavily impacted by the "opioid epidemic," with many lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Despite this, there are numerous resources to combat the epidemic, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions. My son's elementary school is excellent, with wonderful staff and no bullying due to his special needs. The PTO plans family events to enhance involvement and educational progress. The school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. The City Council has improved the town's appearance, with road repaving, landscaping, and park refurbishing, mostly in the center and on the west side. The east side, where I live, is often neglected. Overall, I enjoy living here with friendly people, great schools, adequate shopping, and a comfortable home. We've lived here for over 16 years and can't imagine living elsewhere.

My neighborhood is a cultural hub, nestled on a hill and surrounded by historical buildings. I live in a 7-story apartment building across from an old live theater, and just a block down is a cool little arcade bar that attracts all sorts of people on warm summer nights, often forming a line of eager patrons. A few blocks up, there's a spacious city park with concrete walls and tall steps. During winter, homeless people set up their tents along the sidewalks and steps for warmth. It doesn't snow much, but the rain can be intense, making it challenging to stay warm. They're close to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city isn't its historic architecture or the iconic buildings; it's the people and their culture. Hilltop was once notorious for gang violence, but the residents work hard to keep it clean, and the stories of those days are still passed down. It might be considered one of the rougher 'hoods,' but the people care about their city and block. The warning not to walk around Hilltop after dark, often given to white people, is a reminder of the past and social conditioning. Perhaps it's because I'm dark enough to blend in, or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have offered me a jacket more times than tried to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners stayed open late so I could charge my phone, and where I've sat, feeling invisible, only to be acknowledged and given $5 by a stranger who told me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I call rural Michigan my home, nestled between farmlands and charming tourist towns. There's no big city shopping, no Walmart or Target, not even an Applebee's. Everywhere you need to go, you drive. But I'm lucky to live in one of Mother Nature's most breathtaking spots, with Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix on my doorstep. Anywhere you go, there's a beach waiting. My neighborhood is classic small-town America. Houses aren't stacked, they're unique, with basements visible from the road. You'll find aluminum-siding homes of every color, with yards full of trampolines, playsets, gardens, and fences for furry friends. These are homes of hardworking folks who've raised or are raising families. Kids are always out running around, neighbors wave and walk their dogs, bikes, and rollerblades, while lawns are kept neat and tidy. It's not a fancy neighborhood, but a peaceful, safe one perfect for raising a family. The county sheriff's department and jail are nearby, along with the health department, recycling center, and sports fields. You can hear planes taking off and landing at our small airport. Ice cream is a short walk away, and downtown is just a bike ride. It's a great place to live, a place you can tell is perfect for a family.
